art4_h2_1: 1. Why Neon Colors ‚ÄúGlow‚Äù to the Human Eye
art4_p1: Neon colors feel bright because they stimulate the eye‚Äôs cones more aggressively than muted tones. Highly saturated blues, pinks, cyans, and purples sit near the edges of the visible spectrum, making them pop even against dark backgrounds.
art4_li1_1: üí° High contrast on dark backgrounds ‚Üí instant clarity

art4_li1_3: ‚ö° Motion trails intensify the visual impact
art4_p2: The simplest neon effect in HTML5 uses Canvas 2D shadowBlur and shadowColor to simulate a glowing halo.
art4_p3: This is extremely performant and ideal for bullets, outlines, doors, pickups, and UI highlights.
art4_li2_1: Additive blending ‚Üí overlapping bright pixels intensify
art4_li2_2: Bloom shaders ‚Üí soft glow spreading outward
art4_p4: Neon particles simulate sparks, dust, embers, and energy pulses. They respond dynamically to hits, dashes, collisions, and explosions.
art4_li3_3: Additive blending for bright overlapping particles

art8_intro_1: Collision systems are the backbone of real-time game mechanics. Whether detecting bullet hits, player movement, enemy interactions, or room transitions ‚Äî precision and speed determine how responsive a game feels.
art8_p1: AABBs are the most common hitbox format in HTML5 games. They use simple rectangle overlap logic:
art8_p2: This check is extremely fast ‚Äî ideal for mobile and browser games.
art8_p3: For neon games, pixel-perfect collisions are rarely required. They are expensive because they involve reading pixel buffers via Canvas or WebGL.
art8_p4: High-object scenes often use spatial partitioning structures:
